docs.snippet: Chile and the European Union have concluded an agreement that will free more than $7 billion in trade between the two, the first deal of its kind between Europe and South America. ''Today the dreams of 15 million Chileans are with us, and also the...
docs.lead_paragraph: Chile and the European Union have concluded an agreement that will free more than $7 billion in trade between the two, the first deal of its kind between Europe and South America. ''Today the dreams of 15 million Chileans are with us, and also the hopes of all Latin America,'' the president of Chile, Ricardo Lagos, said at a meeting of leaders of the European Union, Latin America and the Caribbean. The host, Prime Minister José Maria Aznar of Spain, hailed the agreement as a ''landmark in European foreign policy.'' The union is negotiating a similar deal with the Mercosur block of Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay. Emma Daly (NYT)
docs.abstract: Chile and European Union conclude agreement that will free more than $7 billion in trade between two, first deal of its kind between Europe and South America; Chile's Pres Ricardo Lagos and Spain's Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar hail agreement (S)0

docs.snippet: LEST the United States players get too giddy before heading to the World Cup on Thursday, they had the best thing possible happen to them yesterday: they ran into the ninth-rated soccer team in the world.    Just to keep from being eaten alive by the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEST the United States players get too giddy before heading to the World Cup on Thursday, they had the best thing possible happen to them yesterday: they ran into the ninth-rated soccer team in the world. Just to keep from being eaten alive by the talented Dutch team -- which somehow managed not to qualify for the World Cup -- the Americans had to stretch themselves all over the field.
docs.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column contends that US loss to Netherlands in exhibition game is just what national team needed before heading to World Cup; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; The U.S. Gains Humility and Experience

docs.snippet: Michael Owen and Park Ji Sung scored goals as England and South Korea tied, 1-1, in a World Cup warm-up match yesterday in Jejung, South Korea. Park scored the tying goal in the 51st minute.     Another World Cup entry, Uruguay, won by 2-1 at...
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Owen and Park Ji Sung scored goals as England and South Korea tied, 1-1, in a World Cup warm-up match yesterday in Jejung, South Korea. Park scored the tying goal in the 51st minute. Another World Cup entry, Uruguay, won by 2-1 at Singapore behind two goals from Richard Morales. Uruguay is preparing for its first World Cup appearance in 12 years. M.L.S.'S CAREER SCORING LEADER WAIVED: Roy Lassiter, Major League Soccer's career scoring leader, was waived yesterday by the Kansas City Wizards. The team cut Lassiter, 33, along with forward Gary Glasgow of Trinidad and Tobago, to make room on the roster for striker Igor Simutenkov of Russia. Lassiter scored 88 goals during six seasons with Tampa Bay, D.C. United, Miami and Kansas City. Lassiter was traded to the Wizards from Miami before the 2001 season and appeared in 25 games for Kansas City, scoring seven goals and one assist.

docs.snippet: RESNIK-Paul. 64. Died at his home in Santa Fe, NM, on May 20, 2002 from esophageal cancer. Mr. Resnik was born February 12, 1938 and grew up in Stamford, CT. He was the son of Dr. William Resnik, a well-known cardiologist, and Lorraine Smith Resnik,...
docs.lead_paragraph: RESNIK-Paul. 64. Died at his home in Santa Fe, NM, on May 20, 2002 from esophageal cancer. Mr. Resnik was born February 12, 1938 and grew up in Stamford, CT. He was the son of Dr. William Resnik, a well-known cardiologist, and Lorraine Smith Resnik, a musicologist. He is survived by a sister, Kate Resnik Adler, a retired psychologist, of Easton, MD. Mr. Resnik graduated from Brooks School, Yale College and Harvard Law School. He also attended the London School of Economics. In his early career he worked for the Agency for International Development, U.S.State Department, serving in Washington, DC and Uruguay. Later he was a corporate lawyer for ITT in the U.S. and Europe. He also founded The Wine Bar in New York City which he modeled after similar places in Paris. On the basis of his own experience he wrote a book called ''The Small Business Bible,'' which was subsequently translated into several different languages. He then incorporated the principles described in ''The Small Business Bible'' into a joint project with Yale University to help inner-city kids think and express themselves. Mr. Resnik moved from New York to Santa Fe in 1998 and immersed himself in an array of local artistic and philanthropic activities. Among the institutions he supported were the School for American Research and the Southwest Literary Center. In recognition of his contributions, the Southwest Literary Center has announced that a Paul Resnik Narrative Center will be established in his name. He was deeply interested in books and ideas and loved music, art, theater, movies, politics and history. His many friends considered him a man for all seasons, a renaissance man, with a strong social conscience and a searching inquiring mind, an irreverent wit and a deep humanitarian spirit. He was in the process of researching a bold new work on the 1912 elections at the time of his death. Friends are planning a memorial service on July 3 in Santa Fe. In lieu of flowers memorial gifts may be sent to Brooks School Library, North Andover, MA.

docs.snippet: BAHR-Marianne (nee Wolf). Died of natural causes on Tuesday, May 21, 2002 after a long illness. Formerly of Hanover, Germany, Mrs. Bahr was a resident of New York City since 1939. She was the beloved wife of her late husband, Julius Bahr, a coffee...
docs.lead_paragraph: BAHR-Marianne (nee Wolf). Died of natural causes on Tuesday, May 21, 2002 after a long illness. Formerly of Hanover, Germany, Mrs. Bahr was a resident of New York City since 1939. She was the beloved wife of her late husband, Julius Bahr, a coffee importer. The relatives from around the world in Milan, Italy, Sao Paulo, Brazil, South Africa, Mexico, Switzerland, London and Montevideo, Uruguay all mourn her passing. She was a long-standing member of Congregation Rameth Orah. She was an active Director-Trustee of the Wolf Foundation of Tel Aviv Israel, founded by her uncle Richard Wolf, former Cuban Ambassador to Israel. She will be greatly missed by those who had the privilege of knowing this fine human being.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAHR, MARIANNE (NEE WOLF)

docs.snippet: MY boyfriend, Alejandro, an immigrant from Uruguay, works as a mover 10 to 12 hours a day, six days a week. On Sunday, his one day off, I like to declare how much I am looking forward to spending the whole day watching him be handy around the...
docs.lead_paragraph: MY boyfriend, Alejandro, an immigrant from Uruguay, works as a mover 10 to 12 hours a day, six days a week. On Sunday, his one day off, I like to declare how much I am looking forward to spending the whole day watching him be handy around the apartment. That is when he cracks up laughing. You see, Sunday is for soccer and I am a soccer widow. Although the name suggests solitude and grief, I am neither unhappy nor alone.
docs.abstract: Katy McLaughlin article on learning to live with being a soccer widow; says she has learned that non-soccer-playing significant others can enjoy going to games each Sunday; drawing (M)

headline.main: A Sidekick Finds the Open Man

docs.snippet: Having finished last among 32 teams at the 1998 World Cup in France, the United States can take encouragement from this simple fact: It can only get better in 2002.    In truth, there is a buoyancy and a jauntiness about this team that was not...
docs.lead_paragraph: Having finished last among 32 teams at the 1998 World Cup in France, the United States can take encouragement from this simple fact: It can only get better in 2002. In truth, there is a buoyancy and a jauntiness about this team that was not evident four years ago. It is widely considered now that Coach Steve Sampson was in over his head in France and that he was further undermined by a group of fractious, petulant players. Everything that could go wrong did.

docs.snippet: Suddenly, Clint Mathis is the man everybody wants. They want him in Germany. They want him in Italy. And after he plays for the United States national team in South Korea at the World Cup, which starts this week, they may want him in several other...
docs.lead_paragraph: Suddenly, Clint Mathis is the man everybody wants. They want him in Germany. They want him in Italy. And after he plays for the United States national team in South Korea at the World Cup, which starts this week, they may want him in several other countries as well. But the place they need him most is the United States, where, oddly enough, he is least likely to end up. What makes Mathis such a prized commodity is his ability to create goals at any time and from anyplace on the field, the rarest and most precious skill in a sport where a final score of 2-1 reflects a fiesta of rollicking, high-octane offense. No American has ever scored at such a prolific rate as Mathis over the past season and a half or so -- 9 goals and 6 assists in 21 games for the national team, and 20 goals (and 18 assists) in 31 games for his club, the New York/New Jersey MetroStars of Major League Soccer. The goals he scored and set up in 2000 and 2001 propelled the United States to four victories in the early part of the World Cup qualification process, and after he went down with torn knee ligaments last June and the Americans lost several matches before narrowly qualifying, it became clear that he had been the difference between getting to Asia and abject disaster. This year, he returned from the injury and performed brilliantly in several World Cup tuneup games, showcasing not only his magic with the ball but also his fiery temperament and, as important to soccer stardom as anything, his charismatic ability to entertain the crowd. To the national team, which won't get anywhere unless he leads the way again, and to the money-hemorrhaging pro league here that has staked its future on the Americans' performance, Mathis is It.
docs.abstract: Jeff Z Klein profile of top soccer player Clint Mathis, who plays for United States team at World Cup; sees European team likely to lure him away from New York/New Jersey MetroStars of struggling Major League Soccer; photo (M)
